comments: One of Mr Burnett's best.

Owww. Its so sexy.  I love you mister Howlin WOLF

From 1964,even though I was a wee young lad,I remember it!.. My Old Man always had some 'Wolf in his collections..He liked Hubert Sumlin"s(RIP) famous riffs/12-bar blues! and Buddy Guy,on accoustic guitar! on this version,I remember him saying...For me tho,the song and the times of that era have evolved with these versions of "Killing Floor"..Think about it!!!..You had Jimi doing it early on circa 1965-66,as he sat in with Cream,The "Experience  and finally,at "Monterrey Pop" in 'Summer '67 ..You had Led Zep doing "Floor" live in 1968-68..Early performance/live recordings of "Floor"eventually became(Led Zep II's) "The Lemon Song"..What did it for me,was Mike Bloomfield's "Electric Flag" with its intro irrelevance  of "Floor" directed towards then-Prez LBJ--His speech was cut off amid Music and laughter(A few raspberries -" THHHHTTTT"--  thrown in for effect,too !!)..Heady times of youth gone bye!!!
great stuff!!!
i'M THANKFULL THIS MAN HERE INSPIRED JIMMY HENDRIX.GOD BLESS HIS SOUL FOR THAT.
Love this stuff.thank god Jimmy Hendrix did too.
Wolf and Sumlin...A combination made in heaven and that is where they are playing today.  R.I.P.

Both great but Muddy was better!
LOVE IT!

The "killing floor" was the area of a slaughter house where the animals were actually killed. So by extension references to "the killing floor" in blues can mean any time, place or circumstances that are going to lead to violent (and probably lethal) confrontations e.g. a woman caught cheating on her man.

It's an incredibly evocative song title........but what exactly is a Killing Floor? Would one of you marvellous Blues afficianados please enlighten me. I'll go and squeeze my lemon while I'm waiting......
